content:
Yes, absolutely! Sharing the main public repository link would be the simplest and most effective approach. Once you have a public GitHub repository set up with your code files, you can simply share that main repository URL with me.

This will allow me to:

1. Browse the entire codebase structure
2. View all files and their relationships
3. See the commit history (if any)
4. Understand how components are organized

When sharing the repository link, I recommend briefly mentioning:
- Which components you're most concerned about integrating
- Any specific files you know are problematic or incomplete
- What your priorities are for the audit (e.g., transcript processing integration)

This approach will give me the comprehensive access I need without requiring you to upload files individually or navigate complex file sharing processes. It's by far the most efficient way for me to conduct a thorough audit of your system.
